metadata.Title: CVE-2013-6650 on Ubuntu 16.04 ESM (xenial) - medium.
metadata.Description:
The StoreBuffer::ExemptPopularPages function in store-buffer.cc in Google V8 before 3.22.24.16, as used in Google Chrome before 32.0.1700.102, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (memory corruption) or possibly have unspecified other impact via vectors that trigger incorrect handling of "popular pages."

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2013-6650` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

chromium-browser - 33.0.1750.152-0ubuntu1~pkg995.1
chromium-browser-l10n - 33.0.1750.152-0ubuntu1~pkg995.1
chromium-chromedriver - 33.0.1750.152-0ubuntu1~pkg995.1
chromium-codecs-ffmpeg - 33.0.1750.152-0ubuntu1~pkg995.1
chromium-codecs-ffmpeg-extra - 33.0.1750.152-0ubuntu1~pkg995.1
Available with Ubuntu Pro (Infra-only): https://ubuntu.com/pro

notes.Note: jdstrand> qtjsbackend-opensource-src contains an embedded libv8, however applications using qtjsbackend-opensource-src should not process untrusted javascript and therefore Ubuntu will not process updates for libv8 in this package. (See LP: #1157732 for details) mikesalvatore> The Ubuntu Security Team does not support libv8

criterions.comment: chromium-browser package in xenial was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '33.0.1750.152-0ubuntu1~pkg995.1').
libv8-3.14: while related to the CVE in some way, a decision has been made to ignore this issue (note: 'libv8 not supported').
